body_html:
Having links on windows, I am not so sure. How about this, without using a symlink? `tensorflow/__init__.py` includes only a line that says `from tensorflow.v1.10.0 import *` Then all our versions go to `tensorflow/v1.10.0` (or another version). One downside is with similar pip issues, we will accumulate a ton of files on users disks, potentially GBs of stale files.
…
On Sat, Jul 14, 2018 at 7:46 AM Martin Wicke ***@***.***> wrote: Grrrr pip. Can we either add a short (python?) snippet to our install docs that people can run to upgrade safely? Alternatively, could we (going forward) put the python files into a versioned directory, and have "tensorflow" be a link in site-packages? Would that work on Windows? Would it work in pip? — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. body:
Having links on windows, I am not so sure.

How about this, without using a symlink?
`tensorflow/__init__.py` includes only a line that says `from
tensorflow.v1.10.0 import *`

Then all our versions go to `tensorflow/v1.10.0` (or another version).
One downside is with similar pip issues, we will accumulate a ton of files
on users disks, potentially GBs of stale files.


On Sat, Jul 14, 2018 at 7:46 AM Martin Wicke <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Grrrr pip.
>
> Can we either add a short (python?) snippet to our install docs that people
> can run to upgrade safely?
>
> Alternatively, could we (going forward) put the python files into a
> versioned directory, and have "tensorflow" be a link in site-packages?
> Would that work on Windows? Would it work in pip?
>
